reasoning: The critique targets one of the paper’s arguments for why the main candidate ‘easygoing’ class (bounded, difference-making, joint aggregation) is still implausible—specifically the ‘scale tipping’ objection—so it’s somewhat central, but not make-or-break given the paper’s other reasons (dominance worries, pro-extinction worry, and the broader Section 2 fragility case). Substantively, it raises a legitimate parameter-sensitivity/functional-form point (bounded functions differ, and slope/scale matters), but it misdiagnoses the paper’s core concern: the scale-tipping intuition does not primarily rely on approximate linearity near zero; even tanh-like functions can exhibit large value swings from small relative changes once totals are astronomically large and the function is calibrated so that ‘common-sense utopia’ is near the upper bound. Thus it only modestly weakens the attacked claim. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight, but is only partly correct on the mathematical/interpretive dependency it alleges.
title: Scale tipping critique assumes linear bounded functions near zero
